dialogues.text: The sky's POV - the schoolyard. Aaron - sauntering to cla Mary - turning, walking away. We soar through air and mist. Circle a street below. Hove an alley. Descend from the clouds - into the depths of bu and fire escapes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary, among other pedestrians, head homeward. Her pace sa she's in no hurry to get there. Out of an alley and into the street - Hancock, trenchcoat inconspicuous, and in pursuit. J

dialogues.text: Horus waits outside - hands in his pockets. He paces uncomfortably. Roheim exits the liquor store, already imbibing from a br paper BAG. Not a word from Horus.

dialogues.speaker: ROHEIM
dialogues.text: (POST-GULP)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This stuff's going to kill me. He gives Horus a glance. Takes another swig.

dialogues.speaker: ROHEIM, (CONT' D)
dialogues.text: (CONTINUING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You disapprove, I know.

dialogues.speaker: HORUS
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ROHEIM
dialogues.text: Sure you do. You disapprove and yet you allow me to drink... to poison myself. Your friend. Without a word of caution. Not a word. Just take it... you take everything.

dialogues.speaker: HORUS
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ROHEIM
dialogues.text: You're afraid to offend. You don't want to be abrasive. Provocative. (beat; as'Horus squirms) So you suppress. Do nothing. Take it. Roheim takes another gulp.

dialogues.speaker: HORUS
dialogues.text: (pulling teeth) You shouldn't drink.

dialogues.speaker: ROHEIM
dialogues.text: My wife. She left a bad taste in my mouth. I drink to kill-the taste. Horus has no response to this.

dialogues.speaker: ROHEIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (SMILES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a good man, Horus... (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're right. This stuff's no good. It's a coward's way out and I know it. He gives the bottle a guilty stare. Tosses the bottle int nearby garbage can.

dialogues.speaker: ROHEIM, (CONY' D)
dialogues.text: (sick of himself) What the hell. I can learn to love beverage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

200 lbs. of superflesh EXPLODES into a JEWELRY display wi just ahead of Mary's path. Glass showers the scene. Peopl SCREAM. Hancock warbles out from the debris - his trenchcoat redu mere tatters. He pulls a severed SLEEVE from the rubble. at Mary, reposed before him.

dialogues.text: (nothing happened) How are you? In unison, they turn to the UPS vehicle - a .mangled heap steel, STEAM billowing from its ruptured radiator. Hancock shrugs a smiles.

dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.text: Along a street somewhere who cares - Hancock and Mary - i cool stroll. Mary holds his trenchcoat, surveying the dam

Hancock - he's lost.

dialogues.text: What're you:.. how old's this thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary stands alone on the sidewalk, looking up at heaven. eyes search the gray sky for signs of life.- There, overhead - a DOT. It grows in size, getting closer arriving fast... and gradually, it shapes into Hancock.
He swoops into view, straight downward. Pulls on the air and eases into a soft landing - by Mary's side. He is wet from his flight and his hands, 'we notice, are together tightly.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (like a little girl) Let's see.

dialogues.text: You have to be quick.

dialogues.speaker: MARY

dialogues.speaker: HANCOCK

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I saw it, right? A little cloud. She peers into his hands - where only a pool of wetness r And with her fingers, Mary reaches inside to feel the rai Hancock watches this - the innocence in her face, as her touches his. He stares down at her hand... at the wedding ring. Mary-p her hand away.

Hancock looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're tense.

dialogues.speaker: HANCOCK
dialogues.text: I've been tired, lately.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You should slow down. Rest.

dialogues.speaker: HANCOCK
dialogues.text: -So people tell me.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (heat; upon some thought) It must be hard.

dialogues.speaker: HANCOCK
dialogues.text: Hard?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: To always do right... do good when all you want to do is rest.

dialogues.speaker: HANCOCK
dialogues.text: It's harder to not do anything. What am I? It's not for me. It's for... it is about people. Rest? When there is despair? I cannot. I bring relief. I am relief. You know that instant, that split instant of time when you realize that the nightmare... the totality of fear itself... that it's all been a bad dream? That it's safe? That is relief. The infant in my arms... to the hysterical mother. When you can see her face, what's rest? It is self-indulgence. Mary - in some advance stage of "wow."

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Where... who are you?

dialogues.speaker: HANCOCK
dialogues.text: It's not important who I am, Mary. Or what... where I'm from. It doesn't matter. I'm a man. I am every man.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (sizing up his words) You probably get a lot of practice explaining yourself, on account of who you are and what you do.

dialogues.speaker: HANCOCK
dialogues.text: Why... do you say that?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: It's like, everything you say sounds... so perfect. Like you rehearse them so they'll be that way. I mean, not to say that it's insincere... (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, maybe it's something about you but... it must be hard on you sometimes. Hancock stares at his feet, perhaps reluctant to answer.

dialogues.speaker: MARY, (CONT' D)
dialogues.text: (APOLOGETIC)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But probably not... probably..

dialogues.speaker: HANCOCK
dialogues.text: Yes... (pulling teeth) sometimes. Mary allows the moment to sink in.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: So, you never answered. Back there... what were you doing in the middle of the street?

dialogues.speaker: HANCOCK
dialogues.text: (THINKS)

dialogues.text: I was lost... (EXHALES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . but I think I'm ok, now.

Erlick. Spengler. They zoom by and with great eagerness. Perceval strolls after them, too cool to sweat. From the dumpster, little Aaron watches them... looks relieved... until conscience kicks in. A moment to reflec takes.

(at Hancock) sometimes, I need his strength. I miss. the strength.

dialogues.text: (into the mirror) the old man Look at what they did.. gave a fat lip to match his big mouth. I'm for shit.

The things I am capable of doing, I can't blink away the hell I've seen. It's in me... (points to his head) in here and I can't not think about it. It's in me. It's me.
